an4.221:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of bad conduct by way of speech.

an4.221:1.3.pli: Musāvādo, pisuṇā vācā, pharusā vācā, samphappalāpo—
an4.221:1.3.eng: Speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical.

an4.221:1.4.eng: These are the four kinds of bad conduct by way of speech.

an4.221:1.5.eng: There are these four kinds of good conduct by way of speech.

an4.221:1.7.pli: Saccavācā, apisuṇā vācā, saṇhā vācā, mantavācā—
an4.221:1.7.eng: Speech that’s true, harmonious, gentle, and thoughtful.

an4.221:1.8.eng: These are the four kinds of good conduct by way of speech.”

an4.222:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bālo abyatto asappuriso khataṃ upahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo viññūnaṃ; bahuñca apuññaṃ pasavati.
an4.222:1.1.eng: “When a foolish, incompetent untrue person has four qualities they keep themselves broken and damaged. They deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they brim with much wickedness.

an4.222:1.3.eng: Bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and wrong view.

an4.222:1.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bālo abyatto asappuriso khataṃ upahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo viññūnaṃ, bahuñca apuññaṃ pasavati.
an4.222:1.4.eng: When a foolish, incompetent untrue person possesses these four qualities they keep themselves broken and damaged. They deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they create much wickedness.

an4.222:2.1.pli: Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito viyatto sappuriso akkhataṃ anupahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, anavajjo ca hoti ananuvajjo viññūnaṃ, bahuñca puññaṃ pasavati.
an4.222:2.1.eng: When an astute, competent true person has four qualities they keep themselves intact and unscathed. They don’t deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they brim with much merit.

an4.222:2.3.eng: Good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and right view.

an4.222:2.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito viyatto sappuriso akkhataṃ anupahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, anavajjo ca hoti ananuvajjo viññūnaṃ; bahuñca puññaṃ pasavatī”ti.
an4.222:2.4.eng: When an astute, competent true person possesses these four qualities they keep themselves healthy and whole. They don’t deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they create much merit.”

an4.223:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bālo abyatto asappuriso khataṃ upahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo viññūnaṃ, bahuñca apuññaṃ pasavati.
an4.223:1.1.eng: “When a foolish, incompetent untrue person has four qualities they keep themselves broken and damaged. They deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they brim with much wickedness.

an4.223:1.3.eng: Bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and being ungrateful and thankless.

an4.223:1.4.eng: An astute person … brims with much merit. … Good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and being grateful and thankful. …”

an4.224:1.1.pli: …pe… Pāṇātipātī hoti, adinnādāyī hoti, kāmesumicchācārī hoti, musāvādī hoti …pe… pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, musāvādā paṭivirato hoti …pe….
an4.224:1.1.eng: “A foolish person … brims with much wickedness. … They kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, and lie. … An astute person … brims with much merit. … They don’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, or lie. …”

an4.225:1.1.pli: …pe… Micchādiṭṭhiko hoti, micchāsaṅkappo hoti, micchāvāco hoti, micchākammanto hoti …pe… sammādiṭṭhiko hoti, sammāsaṅkappo hoti, sammāvāco hoti, sammākammanto hoti …pe….
an4.225:1.1.eng: “A foolish person … brims with much wickedness. … wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action. … An astute person … brims with much merit. … right view, right thought, right speech, right action. …”

an4.226:1.1.pli: …pe… Micchāājīvo hoti, micchāvāyāmo hoti, micchāsati hoti, micchāsamādhi hoti …pe… sammāājīvo hoti, sammāvāyāmo hoti, sammāsati hoti, sammāsamādhi hoti …pe….
an4.226:1.1.eng: “A foolish person … brims with much wickedness. … wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion. … An astute person … brims with much merit. … right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion. …”

an4.227:1.1.pli: …pe… Adiṭṭhe diṭṭhavādī hoti, asute sutavādī hoti, amute mutavādī hoti, aviññāte viññātavādī hoti …pe… adiṭṭhe adiṭṭhavādī hoti, asute asutavādī hoti, amute amutavādī hoti, aviññāte aviññātavādī hoti …pe….
an4.227:1.1.eng: “A foolish person … brims with much wickedness. … They say they’ve seen, heard, thought, or known something, but they haven’t. … An astute person … brims with much merit. … They say they haven’t seen, heard, thought, or known something, and they haven’t. …”

an4.228:1.1.pli: …pe… Diṭṭhe adiṭṭhavādī hoti, sute asutavādī hoti, mute amutavādī hoti, viññāte aviññātavādī hoti …pe… diṭṭhe diṭṭhavādī hoti, sute sutavādī hoti, mute mutavādī hoti, viññāte viññātavādī hoti …pe….
an4.228:1.1.eng: “A foolish person … brims with much wickedness. … They say they haven’t seen, heard, thought, or known something, but they have. … An astute person … brims with much merit. … They say they’ve seen, heard, thought, or known something, and they have. …”

an4.229:1.1.pli: …pe… Assaddho hoti, dussīlo hoti, ahiriko hoti, anottappī hoti …pe… saddho hoti, sīlavā hoti, hirimā hoti, ottappī hoti …pe….
an4.229:1.1.eng: “A foolish person … brims with much wickedness. … They’re faithless, unethical, shameless, and imprudent. … An astute person … brims with much merit. … They’re faithful, ethical, conscientious, and prudent. …”

an4.23:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the world has been understood by the Realized One;

an4.23:1.2.eng: and he is detached from the world.

an4.23:1.3.eng: The origin of the world has been understood by the Realized One;

an4.23:1.4.eng: and he has given up the origin of the world.

an4.23:1.5.eng: The cessation of the world has been understood by the Realized One;

an4.23:1.6.eng: and he has realized the cessation of the world.

an4.23:1.7.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of the world has been understood by the Realized One;

an4.23:1.8.eng: and he has developed the practice that leads to the cessation of the world.

an4.23:2.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevakassa lokassa samārakassa sabrahmakassa sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, sabbaṃ taṃ tathāgatena abhisambuddhaṃ.
an4.23:2.1.eng: In this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—whatever is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, and explored by the mind, all that has been understood by the Realized One.

an4.23:2.2.eng: That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.

an4.23:3.1.pli: Yañca, bhikkhave, rattiṃ tathāgato anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambujjhati yañca rattiṃ anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyati, yaṃ etasmiṃ antare bhāsati lapati niddisati sabbaṃ taṃ tatheva hoti, no aññathā.
an4.23:3.1.eng: From the night when the Realized One awakens to the supreme perfect awakening until the night he becomes fully extinguished—in the element of extinguishment with no residue—everything he speaks, says, and expresses is real, not otherwise.

an4.23:3.2.eng: That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.

an4.23:4.1.pli: Yathāvādī, bhikkhave, tathāgato tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī.
an4.23:4.1.eng: The Realized One does as he says, and says as he does.

an4.23:4.3.eng: that’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.

an4.23:5.1.pli: Sadevake, bhikkhave, loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya tathāgato abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthu daso vasavattī.
an4.23:5.1.eng: In this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—the Realized One is the vanquisher, the unvanquished, the universal seer, the wielder of power.

an4.23:5.2.eng: That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.

an4.23:6.1.eng: Directly knowing the whole world as it is,

an4.23:6.3.eng: he is detached from the whole world,

an4.23:7.1.eng: That attentive one is the champion

an4.23:7.2.eng: who is released from all ties.

an4.23:7.4.eng: extinguishment, fearing nothing from any quarter.

an4.23:8.1.eng: He is the Buddha, with defilements ended,

an4.23:8.3.eng: He has attained the end of all deeds,

an4.23:8.4.eng: freed with the end of attachments.

an4.23:9.1.eng: That Blessed One is the Buddha,

an4.23:9.3.eng: in all the world with its gods,

an4.23:10.1.eng: And so those gods and humans,

an4.23:10.2.eng: who have gone to the Buddha for refuge,

an4.23:11.1.eng: ‘Tamed, he is the best of tamers,

an4.23:11.2.eng: peaceful, he is the seer among the peaceful,

an4.23:11.3.eng: liberated, he is the foremost of liberators,

an4.23:11.4.eng: crossed over, he is the most excellent of guides across.’

an4.23:12.3.eng: In the world with its gods,

an4.230:1.1.pli: …pe… Assaddho hoti, dussīlo hoti, kusīto hoti, duppañño hoti …pe… saddho hoti, sīlavā hoti, āraddhavīriyo hoti, paññavā hoti—
an4.230:1.1.eng: “A foolish person … brims with much wickedness. … They’re faithless, unethical, lazy, and witless. … An astute person … brims with much merit. … They’re faithful, ethical, energetic, and wise.

an4.230:1.2.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito viyatto sappuriso akkhataṃ anupahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, anavajjo ca hoti ananuvajjo viññūnaṃ, bahuñca puññaṃ pasavatī”ti.
an4.230:1.2.eng: When an astute, competent true person possesses these four qualities they keep themselves healthy and whole. They don’t deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they create much merit.”

an4.231:1.3.eng: A poet who thoughtfully composes their own work, a poet who repeats the oral transmission, a poet who educates, and a poet who improvises.

an4.232:1.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, kammāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni.
an4.232:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I declare these four kinds of deeds, having realized them with my own insight.

an4.232:1.3.eng: There are dark deeds with dark results.

an4.232:1.4.eng: There are bright deeds with bright results.

an4.232:1.5.eng: There are dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results.

an4.232:1.6.pli: atthi, bhikkhave, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati.
an4.232:1.6.eng: There are neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.

an4.232:1.7.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri kammāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditānī”ti.
an4.232:1.7.eng: These are the four kinds of deeds that I declare, having realized them with my own insight.”

an4.233:1.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, kammāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni.
an4.233:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I declare these four kinds of deeds, having realized them with my own insight.

an4.233:1.3.eng: There are dark deeds with dark results;

an4.233:1.5.eng: dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results; and

an4.233:1.6.pli: atthi, bhikkhave, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati.
an4.233:1.6.eng: neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.

an4.233:2.1.eng: And what are dark deeds with dark results?

an4.233:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sabyābajjhaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, sabyābajjhaṃ vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, sabyābajjhaṃ manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti.
an4.233:2.2.eng: It’s when someone makes hurtful choices by way of body, speech, and mind.

an4.233:2.3.pli: So sabyābajjhaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, sabyābajjhaṃ vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, sabyābajjhaṃ manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā sabyābajjhaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
an4.233:2.3.eng: Having made these choices, they’re reborn in a hurtful world,

an4.233:2.4.pli: Tamenaṃ sabyābajjhaṃ lokaṃ upapannaṃ samānaṃ sabyābajjhā phassā phusanti.

an4.233:2.5.pli: So sabyābajjhehi phassehi phuṭṭho samāno sabyābajjhaṃ vedanaṃ vediyati ekantadukkhaṃ, seyyathāpi sattā nerayikā.
an4.233:2.5.eng: Touched by hurtful contacts, they experience hurtful feelings that are exclusively painful—like the beings in hell.

an4.233:2.6.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ kaṇhaṃ kaṇhavipākaṃ.
an4.233:2.6.eng: These are called dark deeds with dark results.

an4.233:3.1.eng: And what are bright deeds with bright results?

an4.233:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco abyābajjhaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, abyābajjhaṃ vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, abyābajjhaṃ manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti.
an4.233:3.2.eng: It’s when someone makes pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind.

an4.233:3.3.pli: So abyābajjhaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, abyābajjhaṃ vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, abyābajjhaṃ manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā abyābajjhaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
an4.233:3.3.eng: Having made these choices, they’re reborn in a pleasing world,

an4.233:3.4.pli: Tamenaṃ abyābajjhaṃ lokaṃ upapannaṃ samānaṃ abyābajjhā phassā phusanti.

an4.233:3.5.pli: So abyābajjhehi phassehi phuṭṭho samāno abyābajjhaṃ vedanaṃ vediyati ekantasukhaṃ, seyyathāpi devā subhakiṇhā.
an4.233:3.5.eng: Touched by pleasing contacts, they experience pleasing feelings of perfect happiness—like the gods of universal beauty.

an4.233:3.6.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ sukkaṃ sukkavipākaṃ.
an4.233:3.6.eng: These are called bright deeds with bright results.

an4.233:4.1.eng: And what are dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results?

an4.233:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti.
an4.233:4.2.eng: It’s when someone makes both hurtful and pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind.

an4.233:4.3.pli: So sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi lokaṃ upapajjati.
an4.233:4.3.eng: Having made these choices, they are reborn in a world that is both hurtful and pleasing,

an4.233:4.4.pli: Tamenaṃ sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi lokaṃ upapannaṃ samānaṃ sabyābajjhāpi abyābajjhāpi phassā phusanti.
an4.233:4.4.eng: where hurtful and pleasing contacts strike them.

an4.233:4.5.pli: So sabyābajjhehipi abyābajjhehipi phassehi phuṭṭho samāno sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi vedanaṃ vediyati vokiṇṇasukhadukkhaṃ, seyyathāpi manussā ekacce ca devā ekacce ca vinipātikā.
an4.233:4.5.eng: Touched by both hurtful and pleasing contacts, they experience both hurtful and pleasing feelings that are a mixture of pleasure and pain—like humans, some gods, and some beings in the underworld.

an4.233:4.6.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ kaṇhasukkaṃ kaṇhasukkavipākaṃ.
an4.233:4.6.eng: These are called dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results.

an4.233:5.1.pli: Katamañca, bhikkhave, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati?
an4.233:5.1.eng: And what are neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds?

an4.233:5.2.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yamidaṃ kammaṃ kaṇhaṃ kaṇhavipākaṃ tassa pahānāya yā cetanā, yamidaṃ kammaṃ sukkaṃ sukkavipākaṃ tassa pahānāya yā cetanā, yamidaṃ kammaṃ kaṇhasukkaṃ kaṇhasukkavipākaṃ tassa pahānāya yā cetanā—
an4.233:5.2.eng: It’s the intention to give up dark deeds with dark results, bright deeds with bright results, and both dark and bright deeds with both dark and bright results.

an4.233:5.3.pli: idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati.
an4.233:5.3.eng: These are called neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.

an4.233:5.4.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri kammāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditānī”ti.
an4.233:5.4.eng: These are the four kinds of deeds that I declare, having realized them with my own insight.”

an4.234:1.1.pli: Atha kho sikhāmoggallāno brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
an4.234:1.1.eng: Then Sikhāmoggallāna the brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

an4.234:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho sikhāmoggallāno brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an4.234:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, Sikhāmoggallāna sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:

an4.234:2.1.pli: “Purimāni, bho gotama, divasāni purimatarāni soṇakāyano māṇavo yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ etadavoca:
an4.234:2.1.eng: “Worthy Gotama, a few days ago the student Soṇakāyana came to me and said:

an4.234:2.2.pli: ‘samaṇo gotamo sabbakammānaṃ akiriyaṃ paññapeti, sabbakammānaṃ kho pana akiriyaṃ paññapento ucchedaṃ āha lokassa’—
an4.234:2.2.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama advocates not doing any deeds. So he teaches the annihilation of the world!’

an4.234:2.3.eng: The world exists through deeds, and it remains because deeds are undertaken.”

an4.234:3.1.pli: “Dassanampi kho ahaṃ, brāhmaṇa, soṇakāyanassa māṇavassa nābhijānāmi;
an4.234:3.1.eng: “Brahmin, I can’t recall even seeing the student Soṇakāyana,

an4.234:3.2.eng: so how could we possibly have had such a discussion?

an4.234:3.3.pli: Cattārimāni, brāhmaṇa, kammāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni.
an4.234:3.3.eng: I declare these four kinds of deeds, having realized them with my own insight.

an4.234:3.5.eng: There are dark deeds with dark results;

an4.234:3.7.eng: dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results; and

an4.234:3.8.pli: atthi, brāhmaṇa, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati.
an4.234:3.8.eng: neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.

an4.234:4.1.eng: And what are the dark deeds with dark results?

an4.234:4.2.pli: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco sabyābajjhaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, sabyābajjhaṃ vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, sabyābajjhaṃ manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti.
an4.234:4.2.eng: It’s when someone makes hurtful choices by way of body, speech, and mind. …

an4.234:4.3.pli: So sabyābajjhaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, sabyābajjhaṃ vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, sabyābajjhaṃ manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā sabyābajjhaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.

an4.234:4.4.pli: Tamenaṃ sabyābajjhaṃ lokaṃ upapannaṃ samānaṃ sabyābajjhā phassā phusanti.

an4.234:4.5.pli: So sabyābajjhehi phassehi phuṭṭho samāno sabyābajjhaṃ vedanaṃ vediyati ekantadukkhaṃ, seyyathāpi sattā nerayikā.
an4.234:4.5.eng: Touched by hurtful contacts, they experience hurtful feelings that are exclusively painful—like the beings in hell.

an4.234:4.6.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, kammaṃ kaṇhaṃ kaṇhavipākaṃ.
an4.234:4.6.eng: These are called dark deeds with dark results.

an4.234:5.1.eng: And what are bright deeds with bright results?

an4.234:5.2.pli: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco abyābajjhaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, abyābajjhaṃ vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, abyābajjhaṃ manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti.
an4.234:5.2.eng: It’s when someone makes pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind. …

an4.234:5.3.pli: So abyābajjhaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, abyābajjhaṃ vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, abyābajjhaṃ manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā abyābajjhaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.

an4.234:5.4.pli: Tamenaṃ abyābajjhaṃ lokaṃ upapannaṃ samānaṃ abyābajjhā phassā phusanti.

an4.234:5.5.pli: So abyābajjhehi phassehi phuṭṭho samāno abyābajjhaṃ vedanaṃ vediyati ekantasukhaṃ, seyyathāpi devā subhakiṇhā.
an4.234:5.5.eng: Touched by pleasing contacts, they experience pleasing feelings of perfect happiness—like the gods of universal beauty.

an4.234:5.6.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, kammaṃ sukkaṃ sukkavipākaṃ.
an4.234:5.6.eng: These are called bright deeds with bright results.

an4.234:6.1.eng: And what are dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results?

an4.234:6.2.pli: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti.
an4.234:6.2.eng: It’s when someone makes both hurtful and pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind. …

an4.234:6.3.pli: So sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā, sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharitvā sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi lokaṃ upapajjati.

an4.234:6.4.pli: Tamenaṃ sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi lokaṃ upapannaṃ samānaṃ sabyābajjhāpi abyābajjhāpi phassā phusanti.

an4.234:6.5.pli: So sabyābajjhehipi abyābajjhehipi phassehi phuṭṭho samāno sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi vedanaṃ vediyati vokiṇṇasukhadukkhaṃ, seyyathāpi manussā ekacce ca devā ekacce ca vinipātikā.
an4.234:6.5.eng: Touched by both hurtful and pleasing contacts, they experience both hurtful and pleasing feelings that are a mixture of pleasure and pain—like humans, some gods, and some beings in the underworld.

an4.234:6.6.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, kammaṃ kaṇhasukkaṃ kaṇhasukkavipākaṃ.
an4.234:6.6.eng: These are called dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results.

an4.234:7.1.pli: Katamañca, brāhmaṇa, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati?
an4.234:7.1.eng: And what are neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds?

an4.234:7.2.pli: Tatra, brāhmaṇa, yamidaṃ kammaṃ kaṇhaṃ kaṇhavipākaṃ tassa pahānāya yā cetanā, yamidaṃ kammaṃ sukkaṃ sukkavipākaṃ tassa pahānāya yā cetanā, yamidaṃ kammaṃ kaṇhasukkaṃ kaṇhasukkavipākaṃ tassa pahānāya yā cetanā—
an4.234:7.2.eng: It’s the intention to give up dark deeds with dark results, bright deeds with bright results, and both dark and bright deeds with both dark and bright results.

an4.234:7.3.pli: idaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati.
an4.234:7.3.eng: These are called neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.

an4.234:7.4.pli: Imāni kho, brāhmaṇa, cattāri kammāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditānī”ti.
an4.234:7.4.eng: These are the four kinds of deeds that I declare, having realized them with my own insight.”

an4.235:1.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, kammāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni.
an4.235:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I declare these four kinds of deeds, having realized them with my own insight.

an4.235:1.3.eng: There are dark deeds with dark results;

an4.235:1.5.eng: dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results; and

an4.235:1.6.pli: atthi, bhikkhave, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati.
an4.235:1.6.eng: neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.

an4.235:1.7.eng: And what are the dark deeds with dark results?

an4.235:1.8.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pāṇātipātī hoti, adinnādāyī hoti, kāmesumicchācārī hoti, musāvādī hoti, surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhāyī hoti.
an4.235:1.8.eng: It’s when someone kills living creatures, steals, commits sexual misconduct, lies, and consumes beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

an4.235:1.9.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ kaṇhaṃ kaṇhavipākaṃ.
an4.235:1.9.eng: These are called dark deeds with dark results.

an4.235:2.1.eng: And what are bright deeds with bright results?

an4.235:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭivirato hoti.
an4.235:2.2.eng: It’s when someone doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or consume beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

an4.235:2.3.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ sukkaṃ sukkavipākaṃ.
an4.235:2.3.eng: These are called bright deeds with bright results.

an4.235:3.1.eng: And what are dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results?

an4.235:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti …pe… idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ kaṇhasukkaṃ kaṇhasukkavipākaṃ.
an4.235:3.2.eng: It’s when someone makes both hurtful and pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind. These are called dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results.

an4.235:4.1.pli: Katamañca, bhikkhave, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati?
an4.235:4.1.eng: And what are neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds?

an4.235:4.2.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yamidaṃ kammaṃ kaṇhaṃ kaṇhavipākaṃ …pe… idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati.
an4.235:4.2.eng: It’s the intention to give up dark deeds with dark results, bright deeds with bright results, and both dark and bright deeds with both dark and bright results. These are called neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.

an4.235:4.3.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri kammāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditānī”ti.
an4.235:4.3.eng: These are the four kinds of deeds that I declare, having realized them with my own insight.”
